31.text: I received my first tooth at the age of two and a half.

36.text: This was, by all accounts, particularly late in a child’s development –

41.text: and meant that I was also late to be weaned.

51.text: I did not enjoy teething so much;

54.text: its unpleasantness developed in me a certain disregard for these hard buds erupting from my gums.

61.text: I found biting with conviction on firm objects to be of benefit and suitable punishment for the teeth.

68.text: I would take to chewing anything I could get my young mandible around.

74.text: Surprisingly, my teeth survived this intentional barbarity only to be defeated by an oh-so-sweet sticky toffee apple.

92.text: and primary teeth are only present to make way for adult teeth.

99.text: and by the age of six and a half,

101.text: I had unfortunately now gained a complete and fresh set.

108.text: I had no interest in their welfare,

111.text: I only had interest in the sugariness that passed them by and settled on my tongue.

118.text: My first adult tooth was not a victim to my thoughtlessness but was in fact knocked out.

124.text: At eleven years of age, a pre-planned “chance meeting” behind the school resulted in an inconspicuous bicuspid, becoming...

136.text: The gap left by this missing tooth was thoroughly explored and enjoyed by my tongue with fond reminiscence.

146.text: I reached the age of forty eight continuing to lose teeth;

151.text: by then, I had lost enough teeth to begin missing them in my day-to-day mastication of food

158.text: even if my tongue was now lavishing in the smoothness of its surrounds.

167.text: I lost three more through medical intervention and through necessity, I gained my first set of dentures.

179.text: It was only then, presented with the disembodied enamels,

184.text: that the full beauty of this substantial link between food, tongue, throat and stomach became apparent.

194.text: I began to place the form of the teeth above the function,

198.text: vetting and analysing food for potential risk of the teeth falling fowl.

204.text: Many foods in fact became avoided... avoided or mashed... filtered, separated and mashed again

213.text: all for the sake of keeping my prosthetic teeth pristine.

222.text: My fascination with teeth soon began to spread outside the realm of my own and into those of other toothed animals.

231.text: I marveled at their efficiency, their specificity.

235.text: These wondrous beasts had no need to worry their minds about their teeth.

240.text: They were blessed with immaculate design;

244.text: I would take inspiration from them.

247.text: I began to think about how I could combine these specialist points

252.text: that perhaps I could improve on my previous God-given and God-inspired dentures.

259.text: I realised the perfect cutting, tearing and mashing tools.

267.text: At the age of sixty-two, I separated the species

272.text: and sorted the teeth into categories of size and shape.

276.text: I gathered my resources and set to work on the construction.

280.text: Through my thorough studies, I became convinced that I had come to a combination of interspecies teeth that could not be better matched.

293.text: My meticulousness meant that they were not finished swiftly,

299.text: but they would be of utmost quality.

305.text: In my seventieth, the impressive and fierce set of teeth were complete.

333.text: I lost the tip of my tongue.
